title: What technology was better 10 years ago than it is now because of too much advancement? - Quora

response.answer_text: Every time I watch a DVD or streaming movie with dark scenes, and you can see the patterns of digitization artifacts in the shadow areas, I lament the loss of the superb contrast ratio of old-school CRT TV’s. Really— people who watch digital copies of ‘dark’ (in terms of lighting, not content) movies don’t know how good that was, or how much it added to the experience. Now, when you see a movie of a dark sky, you see these grainy digital bands of gray that are ugly, distracting and of course, not actually dark.. Presumably, the contrast issue will go away once OLED’s are widely available, but that’s not to say they will re-enode the movies to take advantage of it, good quality dark/light representations in moving images are probably forever a thing of the past…

I’d say typing on a phone. 10 years ago, a Blackberry was the business standard and it had an actual keyboard with keys to press. Over time, the need for a larger screen size made this impractical. if you didn’t have a smartphone, the numerical keypad had several letters for each button. So if “1” was also “abc” you pressed it 3 times to get a “c”. in both cases you could type without looking too much at the keyboard. With on screen virtual keyboards, even (especially?) with autocorrect, that’s a quick route to gobbledegook.

Keyboards and mice were better 10 years ago. These are products that they keep redesigning, since everything must be redesigned every year to make it seem like something new that we need. And we have lost the ground in terms of both aesthetics and ergonomics. The only advancement of keyboards since I started using them in 1984 has been reliable wireless. Otherwise it’s either the same or worse.

“Better” only in the sense of “reached the intersection of usefulness and cost”: smart phones. Phones haven’t fundamentally improved since about ten years ago; they are now reduced to packing in largely useless, gimmicky micro-Photoshop features for cameras that still have teeny lenses but dozens of megapixels with which to record the soft blur.

I would say computers. I’ve recently had a crash and lost Windows 7. The new lap top has Windows 10. And me - Ive gone from a speed typist on my high school manual Underwood to hunt and peck on my Dell laptop.
